article.headline: âHealth care will keep us from going back to the U.S.â: Texas couple who retired to Spain on about $2,000 a month
article.body: Call âem Texpats. Kevin and Susan Bryant, 55 and 48, spent most of their lives in Texas, recently in the retiree hot spot Austin. But âwhen Austin became a miniâSilicon Valley, we were priced out,â Kevin, a now-retired history teacher and principal, tells MarketWatch. The history buff says heâd always wanted to live in Europe â âin a castle, specifically, but I let that part go,â he jokes â and began hunting for where the couple might retire on his educatorâs pension. They considered more than a dozen countries, finally settling on Spain for a variety of reasons, including its relative affordability, its good health care and that his teacherâs pension could qualify as income to help him get residency there. “ Need help finding a place to retire? Contact the MarketWatch Retirement team at HelpMeRetire@marketwatch.com and weâll help you with your search. ” To find the right spot, they toured Spain, rejecting Barcelona because it was too big; Tarragona because it was too far north (they wanted somewhere a little warmer); and PeÃ±Ã­scola, because, though they liked it, Susan jokes, âI could never tell my mother I lived in a town with that name.â DÃ©nia, Spain iStock They found DÃ©nia, a coastal town where they now live, by accident: âLooking at the map one morning, I noticed that a ferry from Ibiza docks at a place called DÃ©nia. I immediately thought that very interesting people go to Ibiza, and many must go by that route, so we should check out this place,â Kevin, who has one grown child, explains. They loved DÃ©nia for a number of reasons, including its historic architecture (thereâs even an ancient Moorish castle for Kevin, if only as a visitor), great food (Unesco named it a Creative City of Gastronomy), four-season climate and coastal location. Plus, Susan adds: âItâs a very family-oriented city with lots of celebrations.â They moved to DÃ©nia in 2016, as chronicled on Facebook. Hereâs what their lives are like now, from costs, to health care to residency and downsides. The cost: The Bryants say they live on Kevinâs pension, and say they âlive very well on $2,000 per month.â They spend about $665 on rent (they live in a two-bedroom apartment near the beach with a shared pool), $82 on electricity, $33 on water, $33 on internet, $44 on phone, $90 on a gym membership, $130 on health insurance and $490 on food each month, they tell MarketWatch. The Bryants. Kevin and Susan Bryant The Bryants save money by not owning a car. They live on a bus line and say they spend about $30 a month taking the bus to and from town. (They note that a taxi home from a dinner out might cost them $12.) “ âHealth care is the thing that will keep us from going back to the U.S. We can afford to grow old gracefully and see doctors here. It will not break us.â ” â Kevin Bryant They spend most of their extra money on travel, having recently hit up the Greek Isles and enjoyed many shorter trips through Spain. They point out that travel within Europe often isnât that pricey because flights are short and low-cost via regional carriers. And mostly they take bus trips to nearby towns including Valencia (about a $13 fare) and Benidorm ($5). Health care: The Bryants say they spend roughly $130 for both of them for private health insurance each month â and theyâve been very pleased with the quality of their care. âI go to the freaking doctor here. I grew up male in Texas â we donât go to the doctor unless something is dangling off or broken,â he jokes. âAny time we need something now we go to see the doctor, we get [an appointment] in a day or two,â he adds, noting that âour doctor is Dutch and speaks five languages â cool guy, too.â Some expats may be able to qualify for the free state health-care system in Spain (here are the guidelines); expats who donât qualify for that â or who want to forgo the sometimes long waits that come with the public system â can buy private insurance to cover themselves. (You can read about the different health-care systems here). He credits his great relationship with the doctor, and excellent experience with the Spanish health system, with catching the cancer spots on his face and head early and offering a treatment that cost less than $100. âIf I was still in the U.S., the cancer spots would still be growing because I wouldnât know it was there,â he says. Kevin and Susan Bryant. Spain is recognized for quality health care: A study published in The Lancet on quality and access to health care places Spain among the worldâs top 20 countries, above the United States, which was ranked 29th. The Bryants are so pleased with the low cost and quality of health care in Spain that they say itâs a major reason theyâll never leave. âHealth care is the thing that will keep us from going back to the U.S. We can afford to grow old gracefully and see doctors here. It will not break us.â He adds: âAs things stand, and as I see them standing into the future, health-care costs in the U.S. completely preclude our ever returning to live there. It would be wonderful to have the option, but we donât.â Residency: The process of getting visas to move to â and now stay in â the country hasnât been smooth at all. When they initially went to the Spanish consulate in Houston in the hopes of moving, they came armed with all the paperwork they were told on the website that they needed â only to be informed that those papers werenât enough. âPeople from Spain were in there and heard the whole thing. I asked them, âIs this the way it always is?â And they all started laughing and saying yes,â Kevin recalls. It took them three trips to the consulate to get their visas. Now they must get their visas renewed to stay in Spain, and Kevin says it has been âa real hassle,â adding: âWe eventually had to hire a lawyer, and our case is in progress. Given another chance, Iâd hire the lawyer straight off and let them do all the work.â Here is an overview on visas for residing in Spain. People eating and drinking at Els Magazinos market in DÃ©nia. iStock The cons: The hardest thing for both Kevin and Susan has been missing their family stateside. âAfter that, lack of instant taste gratification. In a major U.S. city, almost any food craving can be satisfied at any time of day or night,â Kevin says, adding that there is an upside to the lack of options in DÃ©nia, though: It has âmade me a much better cook as I attempt to replicate some tastes.â But he jokes: âI have failed to replicate one of my favorite dishes, cheese enchiladas in chile gravy.â Plus, the language has been âan amusing challengeâ for the Bryants. Kevin studied Spanish in school and âeven remembered some of it,â he says. âI expected to be fluent fairly quickly, but we moved to a place where many speak Valencian rather than Castilian, so my progress is slower than expected.â Susan didnât have any Spanish-language background, but sheâs taking classes and now says that, while she canât converse that well, she can understand and read things better. Bottom line: âItâs a lot more laid back here. People look out for one another,â Susan says. But, she adds, âI love America and always will.â
